<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 280, 171, 291]]<|/det|> # PHYSICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 416, 311]]<|/det|> Paper 5 Planning, Analysis and Evaluation <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 341, 415, 352]]<|/det|> Candidates answer on the Question Paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 361, 369, 372]]<|/det|> No Additional Materials are required. <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 394, 386, 405]]<|/det|> # READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 420, 718, 432]]<|/det|> Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 436, 327, 447]]<|/det|> Write in dark blue or black pen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 451, 608, 463]]<|/det|> You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams, graphs or rough working. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 599, 478]]<|/det|> Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 481, 384, 492]]<|/det|> DO **NOT** WRITE IN ANY BARCODES. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 508, 256, 518]]<|/det|> Answer **all** questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 523, 765, 534]]<|/det|> You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 549, 603, 560]]<|/det|> At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 564, 753, 576]]<|/det|> The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 753, 905, 860]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 873, 106]]<|/det|>
Two identical light sources are viewed from a distance, as shown in Fig 1.1. When the angle \(\theta\) between the light sources is large, they are seen as separate.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 128, 764, 338]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[388, 373, 564, 390]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig 1.1 (not to scale)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 404, 873, 437]]<|/det|>
<pre>The sources are moved closer together. At a particular angle \(\theta_{1}\) the two sources appear as a single source.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 450, 873, 467]]<|/det|>
<pre>It is suggested that \(\theta_{1}\) is directly proportional to the wavelength \(\lambda\) of the light from the sources.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 481, 873, 528]]<|/det|>
<pre>Design a laboratory experiment using two light sources to test the relationship between \(\theta_{1}\) and \(\lambda\). You should draw a diagram, on page 3, showing the arrangement of your equipment. In your account you should pay particular attention to

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 543, 144, 560]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 543, 397, 559]]<|/det|>
the procedure to be followed,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 574, 146, 592]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 574, 415, 590]]<|/det|>
the measurements to be taken,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 605, 146, 623]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 605, 350, 621]]<|/det|>
the control of variables,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 636, 146, 654]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 636, 355, 652]]<|/det|>
the analysis of the data,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 667, 148, 685]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 667, 440, 683]]<|/det|>
the safety precautions to be taken.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[838, 680, 875, 698]]<|/det|>
<mark>[15]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 75, 873, 108]]<|/det|>
A trolley is attached to springs, as shown in Fig 2.1. When the trolley is displaced and then released, the trolley oscillates.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 117, 850, 400]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[462, 415, 528, 432]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 2.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 446, 873, 479]]<|/det|>
A student investigates how the maximum speed \(v\) of a trolley varies with the total mass \(M\) of the trolley.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 492, 873, 524]]<|/det|>
The maximum speed is determined using the time \(t\) taken for the card to pass through a light gate connected to an electronic timer. The length of the card is \(5.0 \pm 0.1 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[302, 676, 650, 693]]<|/det|>
<pre>Question 2 continues on the next page.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 573, 90]]<|/det|> 
It is suggested that \(v\) and \(M\) are related by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 95, 540, 128]]<|/det|>

\[v = A\sqrt{\frac{k}{M}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 135, 752, 152]]<|/det|>

where \(A\) is the initial displacement and \(k\) is the spring constant of the springs.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 166, 146, 184]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 166, 875, 199]]<|/det|>
A graph is plotted of \(v^2\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(1/M\) on the \(x\)-axis. Determine an expression for the gradient in terms of \(A\) and \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[500, 273, 875, 291]]<|/det|>

gradient = ............................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 305, 148, 323]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 305, 475, 322]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[166, 337, 825, 528]]<|/det|>

\(M/\mathrm {kg}\)\(t/\mathrm {s}\)\((1/M)/\mathrm {kg}^{-1}\)\(v^{2}/\mathrm {m}^{2}\mathrm {s}^{-2}\)
